subsection.title: Products
subsection.p: So far we have considered sums and differences of algebraic expressions. Now we take a look at simple products. To simplify a product such as 3(2a), we multiply the numerical factors to find 3(2a)=(3 \cdot 2)a = 6a This calculation is an application of the associative law for multiplication. We can see why the product is reasonable by recalling that multiplication is repeated addition, so that 3(2a) = 2a + 2a + 2a = 6a~~~~~~~~~~~~~\blert{\text{Three terms}}

statement.p: Explain the difference between the expressions 2b+3b and 2(3b).

answer.p: The first expression is a sum and the second one is a product.

subsection.title: The Distributive Law

sidebyside.p: Another useful property for simplifying expressions is the distributive law. First consider a numerical example. Suppose we would like to find the area of the two rooms shown at right. We can do this in two different ways:

li.p: Method 2: Find the area of each room separately and add the two areas together. This gives us \blert{10(12) + 10(8)} = 120+80 = 200~\text{square feet}

subsection.p:
Of course, we get the same answer with either method. However, looking at the first step in each calculation, we see that 10(12+8)= 10(12) + 10(8) We see that there are two ways to compute the expression 10(12+8).
The first way follows the order of operations, adding 12+8 first.
The second way distributes the multiplication to each term inside parentheses; that is, we multiply each term inside the parentheses by 10. \blert{10}(12+8)= \blert{10}(12) + \blert{10}(8)
This last equation is an example of the distributive law.

assemblage.title: Distributive Law
assemblage.p: If a,~ b, and c are any numbers, then \blert{a(b+c) = ab + ac}

assemblage.title: Look Ahead
assemblage.p: If the terms inside parentheses are not like terms, we have no choice but to use the distributive law to simplify the expression.

statement.p: Simplify ~-2(3x-1)

solution.p: We multiply each term inside parentheses by -2: \blert{-2}(3x-1) \amp = \blert{-2}(3x)\blert{-2}(-1) \amp = -6x+2

warning.p:
Compare the three similar expressions: -3x-5x,~~~~~~-3(-5x),~~~~~~-3(-5-x) To simplify these expressions, we must first recognize the operations involved.
The first is a sum of terms. -3x-5x = -8x
The second is a product. -3(-5x) = 15x
The third is an application of the distributive law. -3(-5-x) = 15+3x

statement.p: When do we need the distributive law to simplify an expression?

answer.p: If the terms inside parentheses are not like terms

subsection.title: Solving Equations and Inequalities
subsection.p: If an equation or inequality contains parentheses, we use the distributive law to simplify each side before we begin to solve.

warning.p: The expression on the right side of the equation in is made up of two terms: 3x~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~{-2}(4-x) Remember that we think of all terms as added together, so the minus sign in front of the 2 tells us that 2 is negative. When we apply the distributive law, we multiply each term inside parentheses by -2 to get -8+2x.

subsection.title: Algebraic Expressions
subsection.p: We can often simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms.

statement.p:

Write algebraic expressions for the amount of money Delbert made, and the amount Francine made.
Write and simplify an expression for the total amount of money Delbert and Francine made from aluminum cans.

ol.label: a
ol.li: We multiply the number of pounds collected by the price per pound. Delbert made 23x dollars, and Francine made 47x dollars.

li.p: We add the amount of money Delbert made to the amount Francine made. 23x+47x=70x

statement.p: In , what does x stand for? What does 23x stand for?

answer.p: The fee for a pound of recycled cans; the amount of money Delbert made
